body:
> I believe `TypedArgumentConverter` is missing such an annotation for the return type of its [protected `convert`](https://github.com/junit-team/junit-framework/blob/9e7e122a45d11d51ea2fb2203c5c6f1dad45fbb7/junit-jupiter-params/src/main/java/org/junit/jupiter/params/converter/TypedArgumentConverter.java#L92) method.

I thought that the `T extends @Nullable Object` declaration in `class TypedArgumentConverter<S, T extends @Nullable Object>` covered that already. ðŸ¤”

Whether or not `T` is nullable is determined by the type parameter because T is declared as `T extends @Nullable Object` (see [JSpecify docs](https://jspecify.dev/docs/user-guide/#using-type-variables-in-generic-types)). Changing the `convert` method's return type from `T` to `@Nullable T` would make it impossible to specify that the converter is for a non-nullable type and therefore never returns `null`.

One thing we could do, though, is to change the `Class<T> targetType` constructor parameter to `Class<@NonNull T> targetType`. I'll investigate.

issue.title: Make `targetType` parameter easier to use with class literals

repository.name: junit-framework

- [x] Change is documented in the [User Guide](https://docs.junit.org/snapshot/user-guide/) and [Release Notes](https://docs.junit.org/snapshot/user-guide/#release-notes)

body:
Interestingly, I just looked through the Spring Framework code base, and I see that we (the Spring team) do not annotate the return type for such methods with `@Nullable` _if_ the method declaration is in an interface (See [`RowMapper`](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-framework/blob/92a186b44b4e58a9932c23fe71c243b5e944160a/spring-jdbc/src/main/java/org/springframework/jdbc/core/RowMapper.java#L64)). But... we do annotate the method return type with `@Nullable` in classes that implement a parameterized interface (see [`SingletonSupplier`](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-framework/blob/92a186b44b4e58a9932c23fe71c243b5e944160a/spring-core/src/main/java/org/springframework/util/function/SingletonSupplier.java#L96)).

@sdeleuze, do you recall why we have that discrepancy?

> Whether or not T is nullable is determined by the type parameter because T is declared as T extends @Nullable Object (see [JSpecify docs](https://jspecify.dev/docs/user-guide/#using-type-variables-in-generic-types)). Changing the convert method's return type from T to @Nullable T would make it impossible to specify that the converter is for a non-nullable type and therefore never returns null.

Is this even truly possible at the moment? The public `convert` methods (which are final) have their return type annotated with `@Nullable`.

At least in Kotlin, we could easily make `convert` return a non-nullable result even if the original method is annotated with `@Nullable`.

@sbrannen It really depends of the use case:
 - Sometimes the flexible nullability of the class-level generic type parameter is enough to define the nullability at method level
 - Sometimes you override the flexible nullability of the class-level generic type at method level with an explicit `@NonNull` or `@Nullable`
 - Sometimes the nullability of the class-level generic type is not very meaningful so you go for non-null and specify nullable per method, that's the case for `Mono<T>` and `Flux<T>`, see https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-framework/issues/35376#issuecomment-3250906837.

From a Java / JSpecify perspective, the current `TypedArgumentConverter` nullability seems reasonable to me, but I agree that this `String::class.java as Class<String?>` is ugly. I would advise to ask to the Kotlin team what they recommend here.

Thanks for the very detailed explanation, @sdeleuze. Much appreciated. ðŸ‘ 

@marcphilipp, I saw that you already submitted a PR, but do you want to follow up with the Kotlin team to see what they recommend?
